factoid: Anísya Fëdorovna willingly went to fulfill her errand.
Anísya Fëdorovna brought back the guitar.
Uncle blew the dust off the guitar.
Uncle tapped the guitar case with his bony fingers.
Uncle tuned the guitar.
Uncle settled himself in his armchair.
Uncle took the guitar a little above the fingerboard.
Uncle arched his left elbow with a somewhat theatrical gesture.
Uncle winked at Anísya Fëdorovna.
Uncle struck a single chord that was pure and sonorous.
Uncle began playing in very slow time.
Uncle played the well-known song 'Came a maiden down the street'.
The tune was played with precision and in exact time.
The tune began to thrill in the hearts of Nicholas and Natásha.
The tune aroused in Nicholas and Natásha the same kind of sober mirth as radiated from Anísya Fëdorovna’s whole being.
Anísya Fëdorovna flushed.
Anísya Fëdorovna drew her kerchief over her face.
Anísya Fëdorovna went laughing out of the room.
Uncle continued to play correctly.
Uncle played carefully.
Uncle played with energetic firmness.
Uncle looked with a changed and inspired expression at the spot where Anísya Fëdorovna had just stood.
Something seemed to be laughing a little on one side of Uncle's face under his gray mustaches.
The song grew brisker.
The time grew quicker.
As Uncle ran his fingers over the strings, something seemed to snap.
Natásha shouted 'Lovely, lovely! Go on, Uncle, go on!' as soon as Uncle had finished.
Natásha jumped up and hugged Uncle.
Natásha kissed Uncle.
Natásha said 'Nicholas, Nicholas!' turning to Nicholas.
Natásha asked Nicholas: 'What is it that moves me so?'
Nicholas was greatly pleased by Uncle's playing.
Uncle played the piece over again.
Uncle played once more, running his fingers skillfully over the strings.
Uncle stopped short.
Uncle jerked his shoulders.
Natásha wailed 'Go on, Uncle dear' in an imploring tone as if her life depended on it.
Uncle rose.
Uncle smiled seriously at the merry fellow.
Uncle struck a naïve and precise attitude preparatory to a folk dance.
Uncle exclaimed 'Now then, niece!'
Uncle waved to Natásha the hand that had just struck a chord.
Natásha threw off the shawl from her shoulders.
Natásha ran forward to face Uncle.
Natásha set her arms akimbo.
Natásha made a motion with her shoulders.
Natásha struck an attitude.
The young countess was educated by an émigrée French governess.
The young countess imbibed the spirit from the Russian air she breathed.
The young countess obtained a manner that the pas de châle would long ago have effaced.
The spirit and movements were inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that Uncle had expected of her.

As soon as the young countess struck her pose and smiled triumphantly, proudly, and with sly merriment, the fear that had at first seized Nicholas and others that she might not do the right thing ended.
Nicholas and others admired the young countess.
The young countess did the right thing with such precision.
Anísya Fëdorovna handed the young countess a handkerchief she needed for the dance.
Anísya Fëdorovna had tears in her eyes.
Anísya Fëdorovna laughed as she watched the young countess.
The young countess was slim and graceful.
The young countess was reared in silks and velvets.
The young countess was so different from Anísya.
The young countess was able to understand all that was in Anísya and in Anísya’s father and mother and aunt, and in every Russian man and woman.
Uncle cried 'Well, little countess; that’s it—come on!' with a joyous laugh, having finished the dance.
Uncle said 'Well done, niece! Now a fine young fellow must be found as husband for you. That’s it—come on!'
Nicholas said 'He’s chosen already,' smiling.
Uncle said 'Oh?' in surprise.
Uncle looked inquiringly at Natásha.
Natásha nodded her head with a happy smile.
